ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
- geographical analysis
- field work + writing about it
- critical thinking about space place and landscape
- geography in general
observation and reading recall skills

I thought this class did a great job of giving us the tools and knowledge for thinking critically about geography! this definitely provided me with a completely new perspective on place, and the things that we discussed in this class are concepts that I'll consider with places i've already been to and places I am in the future!

I learned how to conduct some geographical research methods and how to think about space from the perspective of a critical geographer. This class gave me the tools to think about how physical places and space shape our lives and how they are related to countless social issues today. We talked about space and place not only from the perspective of geographers but also from critical theorists on race and class and gender. Overall this class helped me understand how I relate to place and how others relate to it as well.
I learned about geography, and the ways in which geography can be understood as an extension of social structures and power dynamics! My writing skills also improved.
Familiarity with frameworks in radical human geography. The distinction between space, place, and landscape.

We learned about the histories and theories of space, place, and landscape - how the concepts are different, but connected. Counter-mapping was my favorite assignment, building off the lesson that maps, like other pieces of text, speak. Creating my own map allowed me to tell a very personal story. As people and maps attempt to define and represent particular places, the discussion of power is necessary to understand this process of meaning-making. I was also so struck by Don Mitchell's landscape axioms that I continue carrying them into my current work at the Peabody as an exhibit assistant writing labels for the North American Dioramas.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The field work was the greatest strength of this course, and I enjoyed the opportunity to learn from non-textual sources. For me, the class discussions and essay feedback were two weaknesses of the course. In general, the discussions closely followed the texts, to the extent that class participation was largely just the regurgitation of facts from readings. This was particularly disappointing given the interesting field work/materials that my peers and I could have presented and discussed, so I think that a shift of discussion focus from readings to field work could greatly improve this class. The essay feedback also fell short for methe grading was so focused on fairly rudimentary structural elements (i.e. thesis statement, paragraphs, etc.) that it was difficult to make any nuanced claims. I also felt that, in order to receive a good grade on a paper, I needed to fully agree with the professor/TA, which resulted in me cutting back on the ideas that I wanted to explore.

strengths: field projects and flexibility

weaknesses: seminar encouraged us to recall readings more than allowing us to discuss ideas. would probably be better in person though

what a great class!!! I really really enjoyed the aspects of place we explored and also the projects we did! one thing to consider might be opening up the discussions a bit more --  I know it's tough over zoom and you folks did an awesome job adapting to virtual, but I think it would be so interesting for class discussions to be a little less structured so conversations can meander a little more! Honestly this might be more doable for an in-person class because I know our time was shorter to prevent zoom screen time (which I really appreciate) but just something to think about for the future. even still, classes were SO engaging and interesting and I honestly did look forward to this class every week!

I think this class had a great organizational structure. The weekly readings were sometimes long but usually very manageable and always engaging and interesting. We had a fair amount of work but it was spread out throughout the semester so we never had too much work due at the same time. Our discussions were usually very well organized, and the projects had clear directions and expectations. One weakness of the course was the turnaround time between class and the time the projects were due. Since we normally went over our projects a bit during class, sometimes it was tough to finish class at 5 and then turn in the project by midnight. Overall though I really enjoyed every single class session and I learned so much from my peers and professors.

This course packed a lot of work into a short amount of time (weekly papers, field projects, and readings), which was difficult around midterm season. By the end of the semester though, I didn't mind it! The material is engaging enough that it honestly wasn't that bad. I also think the field projects were really fun and exciting - Prof Barraclough is deeply committed to transformative education and allowing students to do practical field work, which made the class all the more engaging! I also received clear feedback on every paper, which was nice.
Strengths: Really good readings and discussion set-up in class. Having smaller discussion groups within the seminar group was very helpful! Check-in weeks are very helpful too.

I love how the course was split into the theoretical and practical framework. As a person who struggles to learn from reading thick texts of theory, the weekly field project assignments allowed me to play with different geographical ideas and see first-hand their productivity and their problems. The short essays also constantly pushed me as a writer to make my ideas more succinct without sacrificing style.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You did an awesome job! Again, I really appreciated that you made meeting times slightly shorter to accommodate screen exhaustion! the instructors were honestly so empathetic and flexible and I think they did a wonderful job of making sure we're still getting what we need and contributing what we need to the class while still acknowledging the absolutely wild circumstances this past year.
I think it all worked quite well, particularly the final virtual exhibit of home!
Breakout rooms were actually good! Having a notetaker was very helpful and should be used outside of virtual learning.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I don't believe that I would recommend this course to another student. The professor was kind and the material was interesting, but I don't think that the in class discussions or short paper assignments really helped me learn much. The field work was interesting, but I think I may have gotten as much from doing the field work and readings as I did from taking the class.
I would recommend this course if you are very interested in learning about a certain place or in cultural geography
YES take this class!!! I absolutely loved it and it's been so useful to me in reevaluating how I interact with New Haven and the places around me more broadly

YES!! This is probably my favorite class I have taken at Yale so far. It is a fair amount of work but if you are at all interested in space/evst/urban studies this class is so interesting and I think ties in so many important ideas that we should all think about when we think of space and geography. The professor organizes class in a way that makes sense and helps you build on previous knowledge. I always feel like I got so much from the class discussions, and could relate many of the topics from the readings to my own life.

DO NOT take a class from professor Barraclough if you are sick, disabled, or have any life circumstances that might make your participation a challenge. She claims to be willing to be flexible and supportive but will be neither. I should have trusted the negative reviews of her indigenous geographies class (2019 Fall, ER&M 320), as the instructor they describe was exactly the instructor I received. Read them before you take any class from her.
I absolutely would! The material is interesting for students in any major, and the field projects allow students to actually apply everything that they learn, which is extremely gratifying!
Absolutely! This class really makes me wish we had more critical/radical geography classes at Yale.
Yes! It was my favorite course this Spring, and I think it offers a strikingly different approach to geography than most students might be used to.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In addition to the virtual seminar, this course included field work.
virtual seminar
field projects
N/A
In addition to the virtual seminar dedicated to discussing readings, we did a lot of field work to accompany our original research.
